root.publications: Campbell, Lyle , Ives Goddard, Victor Golla, J. Lachlan Mackenzie, Marianne Mithun & Mauricio J. Mixco. 2007. Atlas of the World's Languages, 2 edn., 8. London, New York: Routledge.

child.publications: Mithun, Marianne. 1999. The Languages of Native North America, 560. Cambridge: Cambridge University Press. ISBN 0-521-23228-7

child.pub-comments: Patwin is one of the two languages of the Wintuan family of norther California, and was originally spoken in two major dialects or dialect clusters along the Sacremento River from Colusa south to the Delta and in the foothills of the Coast range to the west. Descendants live on small rancherias at Cortina and Colusa, and on the Rumsey (Cache Creek) Rancheria west of Woodland. In 1997 at least one speaker of the Hill dialect remained.
child.publications: Campbell, Lyle , Ives Goddard, Victor Golla, J. Lachlan Mackenzie, Marianne Mithun & Mauricio J. Mixco. 2007. Atlas of the World's Languages, 2 edn., 8. London, New York: Routledge.

child.pub-comments: Wintu is one of the two languages in the Wintuan family of northern California, and was originally spoken in the northern half of the Sacremento River below Mt. Shasta, and the upper drainage of the trinity River and on Hayford Creek in trinity County. There were two major dialects, Nomlaki, spoken along the Sacramento River south of red Bluff, and Wintu, spoken elsewhere in teh territory. There appears to have been no significant difference between the variety of Wintu spoken in the trinity-Hayfork area and the Sacramento valley variety. At least one fluent, traditional speaker of the Wintyu dialect remains, although elderly, as well as several semi-speakers.
